options: Forum internum is limited, forum externum is absolute
Forum internum (inner belief) is absolute, forum externum (manifestation) can be limited
They refer to domestic vs international courts
optionsSL: Forum internum je omejen, forum externum je absoluten
Forum internum (notranje prepričanje) je absoluten, forum externum (izražanje) se lahko omeji
Nanašata se na domača in mednarodna sodišča
questions.explanation: Forum internum (the internal dimension - freedom to have beliefs) is absolute and non-derogable. Forum externum (the external dimension - manifestation of religion) can be subject to limitations under Article 18(3).
questions.explanationSL: Forum internum (notranja razsežnost - svoboda imeti prepričanja) je absoluten in se ne more derogirati. Forum externum (zunanja razsežnost - izražanje vere) se lahko omeji po členu 18(3).
questions.examTip: Key distinction for Seminar 1: The internal belief is ALWAYS protected!

questions.question: Under Article 18(3) ICCPR, what are the permitted grounds for limiting the manifestation of religion?
questions.questionSL: Kateri so dovoljeni razlogi za omejevanje izražanja vere po členu 18(3) MPDPP?
options: Public order, morals, and state interests
Public safety, order, health, morals, or fundamental rights and freedoms of others
Any legitimate aim prescribed by law
optionsSL: Javni red, morala in državni interesi
Javna varnost, red, zdravje, morala ali temeljne pravice in svoboščine drugih
Kateri koli legitimen cilj, predpisan z zakonom
questions.explanation: Article 18(3) allows limitations that are prescribed by law and necessary to protect public safety, order, health, or morals, or the fundamental rights and freedoms of others. Note: national security is NOT listed.
questions.explanationSL: Člen 18(3) dopušča omejitve, ki so predpisane z zakonom in nujne za varstvo javne varnosti, reda, zdravja ali morale ali temeljnih pravic in svoboščin drugih. Opomba: nacionalna varnost NI navedena.
questions.examTip: Compare with ECHR Art 9(2) which is similar but not identical!

questions.question: What does General Comment 22 say about coercion to change one's religion?
questions.questionSL: Kaj pravi Splošna pripomba 22 o prisili za spremembo vere?
options: It is permitted under certain circumstances
questions.explanation: General Comment 22 (para. 5) states that Article 18 prohibits coercion that would impair the right to have or adopt a religion, including the use or threat of physical force or penal sanctions.
questions.explanationSL: Splošna pripomba 22 (odst. 5) navaja, da člen 18 prepoveduje prisilo, ki bi posegala v pravico imeti ali sprejeti vero, vključno z uporabo ali grožnjo s fizično silo ali kazenskimi sankcijami.

questions.question: What does Article 27 ICCPR protect?
questions.questionSL: Kaj varuje člen 27 MPDPP?
options: Rights of persons belonging to minorities to enjoy their culture, religion, and language
optionsSL: Pravice pripadnikov manjšin, da uživajo svojo kulturo, vero in jezik
questions.explanation: Article 27 protects the rights of persons belonging to ethnic, religious, or linguistic minorities to enjoy their own culture, profess and practice their own religion, or use their own language. It is an individual right exercised in community.
questions.explanationSL: Člen 27 varuje pravice pripadnikov etničnih, verskih ali jezikovnih manjšin, da uživajo svojo kulturo, izpovedujejo in prakticirajo svojo vero ali uporabljajo svoj jezik. Gre za individualno pravico, ki se izvršuje v skupnosti.
questions.examTip: Note: Article 27 uses 'shall not be denied' - a negative formulation, not positive obligations!

questions.question: Article 27 ICCPR imposes positive obligations on states to actively promote minority cultures.
questions.questionSL: Člen 27 MPDPP državam nalaga pozitivne obveznosti za aktivno spodbujanje manjšinskih kultur.
questions.explanation: Article 27 uses negative formulation ('shall not be denied'). However, the Human Rights Committee in General Comment 23 has interpreted some positive measures may be necessary for effective protection.
questions.explanationSL: Člen 27 uporablja negativno formulacijo ('se ne sme odreči'). Vendar je Odbor za človekove pravice v Splošni pripombi 23 razlagal, da so lahko potrebni nekateri pozitivni ukrepi za učinkovito varstvo.
questions.examTip: Compare with the more explicit positive obligations in FCNM!

questions.question: How many members does the Human Rights Committee have?
questions.questionSL: Koliko članov ima Odbor za človekove pravice?
questions.explanation: The Human Rights Committee consists of 18 independent experts who serve in their personal capacity (not as state representatives). They are elected by states parties to the ICCPR.
questions.explanationSL: Odbor za človekove pravice sestavlja 18 neodvisnih strokovnjakov, ki služijo v osebnem svojstvu (ne kot predstavniki držav). Izvolijo jih države pogodbenice MPDPP.

questions.question: What is the principle of 'progressive realization' in ICESCR?
questions.questionSL: Kaj je načelo 'postopnega uresničevanja' v MPESKP?
options: States can ignore economic rights until they are wealthy
States must take steps to the maximum of available resources to progressively achieve full realization of rights
Rights must be achieved within 10 years
Only democratic states must realize these rights
optionsSL: Države lahko ignorirajo ekonomske pravice, dokler niso bogate
Države morajo sprejeti ukrepe do maksimuma razpoložljivih virov za postopno doseganje polnega uresničenja pravic
Pravice morajo biti dosežene v 10 letih
Samo demokratične države morajo uresničevati te pravice
questions.explanation: Article 2(1) ICESCR requires states to take steps 'to the maximum of its available resources' to achieve 'progressively' the full realization of covenant rights. This acknowledges resource constraints while still creating obligations.
questions.explanationSL: Člen 2(1) MPESKP zahteva od držav, da sprejmejo ukrepe 'do maksimuma razpoložljivih virov' za 'postopno' doseganje polnega uresničenja pravic iz pakta.
questions.examTip: Key for Seminar 2: Progressive realization doesn't mean states can do nothing!

questions.question: What are 'minimum core obligations' under ICESCR?
questions.questionSL: Kaj so 'minimalne temeljne obveznosti' po MPESKP?
options: Obligations that only apply to wealthy states
The bare minimum of each right that must be satisfied immediately, regardless of resources
Obligations that can be derogated in emergencies
Guidelines that are not legally binding
optionsSL: Obveznosti, ki veljajo samo za bogate države
Goli minimum vsake pravice, ki mora biti izpolnjen takoj, ne glede na vire
Obveznosti, od katerih se lahko odstopi v izrednih razmerah
questions.explanation: The CESCR Committee developed 'minimum core obligations' doctrine in General Comment 3, stating that states must ensure minimum essential levels of each right regardless of resource constraints. Failure to do so creates a presumption of violation.
questions.explanationSL: Odbor CESCR je razvil doktrino 'minimalnih temeljnih obveznosti' v Splošni pripombi 3, ki navaja, da morajo države zagotoviti minimalne bistvene ravni vsake pravice ne glede na omejitve virov.
questions.examTip: Example: minimum core of right to food = freedom from hunger.

questions.question: What does UPR stand for?
questions.questionSL: Kaj pomeni kratica UPR (SPP)?
questions.explanation: UPR (Universal Periodic Review / Splošni periodični pregled) is a unique process of the Human Rights Council that reviews the human rights record of all 193 UN member states every 4.5 years.
questions.explanationSL: SPP (Splošni periodični pregled / Universal Periodic Review) je edinstven proces Sveta za človekove pravice, ki pregleduje stanje človekovih pravic vseh 193 članic OZN vsakih 4,5 leta.
questions.examTip: Key for Seminar 3: UPR reviews ALL states, not just those with problems!

questions.question: What is a 'troika' in the UPR process?
questions.questionSL: Kaj je 'trojka' v procesu SPP?
options: Three rapporteurs who facilitate the review
questions.explanation: The troika consists of three states selected by drawing of lots to facilitate the review, including preparation of the Working Group report. One member must be from the same regional group as the state under review.
questions.explanationSL: Trojko sestavljajo tri države, izbrane z žrebom, ki olajšujejo pregled, vključno s pripravo poročila Delovne skupine. En član mora biti iz iste regionalne skupine kot država v pregledu.

questions.question: What are the three documents prepared for UPR review?
questions.questionSL: Kateri trije dokumenti se pripravijo za SPP pregled?
options: Legal brief, NGO report, UN report
National report, UN compilation, stakeholder summary
State report, OHCHR assessment, civil society input
Government position, treaty body views, special procedures findings
optionsSL: Pravni dokument, poročilo NVO, poročilo OZN
Nacionalno poročilo, kompilacija OZN, povzetek deležnikov
Poročilo države, ocena OHCHR, prispevek civilne družbe
Vladna pozicija, stališča pogodbenih teles, ugotovitve posebnih postopkov
questions.explanation: Three documents form the basis for UPR: (1) National report by the state (20 pages), (2) UN compilation of treaty body and special procedures info (10 pages), (3) Summary of stakeholder submissions including NGOs (10 pages).
questions.explanationSL: Tri dokumenti tvorijo osnovo za SPP: (1) Nacionalno poročilo države (20 strani), (2) Kompilacija OZN informacij pogodbenih teles in posebnih postopkov (10 strani), (3) Povzetek prispevkov deležnikov, vključno z NVO (10 strani).
questions.examTip: Know these three 'pillars' of UPR documentation!

questions.question: What happens when a state 'notes' rather than 'accepts' a UPR recommendation?
questions.questionSL: Kaj se zgodi, ko država 'vzame na znanje' namesto 'sprejme' priporočilo SPP?
options: It must implement the recommendation anyway
It effectively rejects the recommendation without formal rejection
A follow-up mechanism is automatically triggered
optionsSL: Dejansko zavrne priporočilo brez formalne zavrnitve
questions.explanation: 'Noted' recommendations are effectively rejected. States often 'note' recommendations they disagree with but don't want to formally reject. 'Accepted' recommendations create at least a political commitment to implement.
questions.explanationSL: 'Vzeta na znanje' priporočila so dejansko zavrnjena. Države pogosto 'vzamejo na znanje' priporočila, s katerimi se ne strinjajo, a jih ne želijo formalno zavrniti.
questions.examTip: Analyze patterns: which countries 'note' many recommendations?

questions.question: What principle did the Ireland v. United Kingdom case establish regarding Article 3 ECHR?
questions.questionSL: Katero načelo je uveljavila zadeva Irska proti Združenemu kraljestvu glede člena 3 EKČP?
options: The distinction between torture and inhuman/degrading treatment
optionsSL: Razlikovanje med mučenjem in nečloveškim/ponižujočim ravnanjem
Člen 3 se uporablja samo v vojnem času
Države se lahko derogirajo od člena 3
questions.explanation: Ireland v. UK (1978) established the threshold distinction: torture requires a particularly serious and cruel level of suffering, with purposive element. The 'five techniques' used by UK were found to be inhuman and degrading, but not torture.
questions.explanationSL: Irska proti UK (1978) je uveljavila razlikovanje praga: mučenje zahteva posebej resno in kruto raven trpljenja z namenskim elementom. 'Pet tehnik', ki jih je uporabila UK, je bilo ugotovljeno kot nečloveško in ponižujoče, a ne mučenje.

questions.question: What did the Osman v. UK case establish?
questions.questionSL: Kaj je uveljavila zadeva Osman proti Združenemu kraljestvu?
options: The right to a fair trial
Positive obligations under Article 2 to protect life
optionsSL: Pozitivne obveznosti po členu 2 za varstvo življenja
questions.explanation: Osman v. UK (1998) established that Article 2 includes positive obligations on states to take preventive measures to protect individuals whose lives are at risk, where authorities knew or ought to have known of a real and immediate threat.
questions.explanationSL: Osman proti UK (1998) je uveljavila, da člen 2 vključuje pozitivne obveznosti držav, da sprejmejo preventivne ukrepe za varstvo posameznikov, katerih življenje je ogroženo, kjer so oblasti vedele ali bi morale vedeti za resnično in neposredno grožnjo.
questions.examTip: The 'Osman test' is crucial for positive obligations under Article 2!

questions.question: What is the 'living instrument' doctrine?
questions.questionSL: Kaj je doktrina 'živega instrumenta'?
options: The ECHR applies only to living persons
The ECHR must be interpreted in light of present-day conditions
The ECHR can be amended easily
The ECHR applies to medical ethics
optionsSL: EKČP se uporablja samo za žive osebe
EKČP je treba razlagati v luči današnjih razmer
EKČP se uporablja za medicinsko etiko
questions.explanation: The 'living instrument' doctrine (from Tyrer v. UK, 1978) means the ECHR must be interpreted in light of present-day conditions, not the conditions when it was drafted. This allows the Convention to evolve with society.
questions.explanationSL: Doktrina 'živega instrumenta' (iz Tyrer proti UK, 1978) pomeni, da je treba EKČP razlagati v luči današnjih razmer, ne razmer ob njeni sestavi. To omogoča, da se konvencija razvija s družbo.
questions.examTip: Key interpretive principle - allows dynamic interpretation!

questions.question: How long does an applicant have to file a case with the ECtHR after exhausting domestic remedies?
questions.questionSL: Koliko časa ima pritožnik za vložitev zadeve pri ESČP po izčrpanju domačih pravnih sredstev?
questions.explanation: Since Protocol 15 (2021), the time limit is 4 months from the final domestic decision (previously 6 months). This applies to applications lodged from February 1, 2022.
questions.explanationSL: Od Protokola 15 (2021) je rok 4 mesece od končne domače odločitve (prej 6 mesecev). To velja za vloge, vložene od 1. februarja 2022.
questions.examTip: Important change! Previously it was 6 months.

questions.question: What is the 'victim requirement' for ECtHR applications?
questions.questionSL: Kaj je 'zahteva po žrtvi' za vloge pri ESČP?
options: The applicant must claim to be a victim of a Convention violation
The violation must have caused physical harm
optionsSL: Samo žrtve kaznivih dejanj lahko vložijo
Pritožnik mora trditi, da je žrtev kršitve konvencije
questions.explanation: Article 34 ECHR requires applicants to be 'victims' - they must claim to be directly affected by the alleged violation. There is no actio popularis - you cannot bring cases in the general public interest.
questions.explanationSL: Člen 34 EKČP zahteva, da so pritožniki 'žrtve' - morajo trditi, da so neposredno prizadeti z domnevno kršitvijo. Ni actio popularis - ni mogoče vlagati zadev v splošnem javnem interesu.

questions.question: What is a 'pilot judgment' procedure in the ECtHR?
questions.questionSL: Kaj je postopek 'pilotne sodbe' pri ESČP?
options: A preliminary ruling before the main case
A judgment identifying systemic problems and requiring general measures
A judgment by a single judge
An experimental procedure not yet finalized
optionsSL: Sodba, ki identificira sistemske probleme in zahteva splošne ukrepe
Eksperimentalni postopek, ki še ni dokončan
questions.explanation: The pilot judgment procedure (from Broniowski v. Poland, 2004) is used when there's a systemic/structural problem causing many similar cases. The Court identifies the problem and requires general measures, while similar cases are adjourned.
questions.explanationSL: Postopek pilotne sodbe (iz Broniowski proti Poljski, 2004) se uporablja, ko sistemski/strukturni problem povzroča veliko podobnih zadev. Sodišče identificira problem in zahteva splošne ukrepe, medtem ko se podobne zadeve preložijo.

questions.question: What did the Soering v. UK case establish about extradition?
questions.questionSL: Kaj je uveljavila zadeva Soering proti Združenemu kraljestvu glede izročitve?
options: Article 3 prohibits extradition where there's a real risk of torture or inhuman treatment
The death penalty always violates Article 3
optionsSL: Člen 3 prepoveduje izročitev, kjer obstaja resnična nevarnost mučenja ali nečloveškega ravnanja
questions.explanation: Soering v. UK (1989) established that Article 3 creates an implied prohibition on extradition or deportation where substantial grounds exist for believing the person faces a real risk of torture or inhuman/degrading treatment.
questions.explanationSL: Soering proti UK (1989) je uveljavila, da člen 3 ustvarja implicirano prepoved izročitve ali deportacije, kjer obstajajo tehtni razlogi za prepričanje, da oseba tvega resnično nevarnost mučenja ali nečloveškega/ponižujočega ravnanja.
questions.examTip: This extended Article 3 protection extraterritorially!

questions.question: What is the 'Lautsi' case about?
questions.questionSL: O čem je zadeva 'Lautsi'?
options: Crucifixes in Italian public school classrooms
optionsSL: Križi v italijanskih javnih šolskih učilnicah
questions.explanation: Lautsi v. Italy (Grand Chamber, 2011) concerned crucifixes in Italian public school classrooms. The GC found no violation of Article 2 Protocol 1 (education) or Article 9, applying wide margin of appreciation for 'passive' religious symbols.
questions.explanationSL: Lautsi proti Italiji (Veliki senat, 2011) se je nanašala na križe v italijanskih javnih šolskih učilnicah. VS ni ugotovil kršitve člena 2 Protokola 1 (izobraževanje) ali člena 9, ob uporabi širokega polja proste presoje za 'pasivne' verske simbole.
questions.examTip: Compare with S.A.S. v. France (Islamic face-covering ban)!

questions.question: What are the judicial formations of the ECtHR?
options: Single judge, Committee, Chamber, Grand Chamber
questions.explanation: The ECtHR has four judicial formations: Single judge (inadmissibility), Committee of 3 judges (repetitive cases), Chamber of 7 judges (most cases), and Grand Chamber of 17 judges (important cases, relinquishment, referral).

questions.question: What is 'just satisfaction' under Article 41 ECHR?
options: Criminal punishment for the violating state
Compensation awarded to the victim when domestic law only allows partial reparation
Membership suspension from Council of Europe
questions.explanation: Article 41 allows the Court to award 'just satisfaction' (compensation) to the injured party if the state's internal law allows only partial reparation. This typically includes pecuniary and non-pecuniary damages, plus costs.

questions.question: Which body supervises the execution of ECtHR judgments?
options: The Committee of Ministers of the Council of Europe
questions.explanation: Under Article 46(2) ECHR, the Committee of Ministers supervises execution of judgments. States must take individual measures (for the applicant) and general measures (to prevent similar violations).

questions.question: What is the 'best interests of the child' principle?
options: Children always get what they want
A primary consideration in all actions concerning children
questions.explanation: Article 3 CRC establishes that 'in all actions concerning children... the best interests of the child shall be a primary consideration.' This is a guiding principle for all decisions affecting children.

questions.question: Which is the most widely ratified human rights treaty?
options: CRC (Convention on the Rights of the Child)
questions.explanation: The CRC is the most widely ratified human rights treaty with 196 state parties. Only the United States has not ratified it (though it has signed).

questions.question: What does CEDAW stand for?
options: Convention on Economic Development and Women
Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women
Committee for Equal Development and Welfare
Charter of European Democratic and Women's Rights
questions.explanation: CEDAW (1979) is the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women, often called the 'women's bill of rights.' It has 189 state parties.

questions.question: What is the Istanbul Convention?
options: A treaty on freedom of religion
Council of Europe convention on preventing and combating violence against women
questions.explanation: The Istanbul Convention (2011) is the Council of Europe Convention on preventing and combating violence against women and domestic violence. It's the most comprehensive international treaty on this issue.

questions.question: What paradigm shift did CRPD introduce for disability rights?
options: From social model to medical model
From medical model to social/human rights model
questions.explanation: CRPD (2006) shifted from the medical model (disability as individual deficiency) to the social/human rights model (disability as result of barriers in society). Focus moved to removing barriers and ensuring equal participation.

questions.question: What is 'reasonable accommodation' under CRPD?
options: Necessary modifications to ensure equal enjoyment of rights without disproportionate burden
questions.explanation: Article 2 CRPD defines reasonable accommodation as necessary and appropriate modifications not imposing disproportionate burden, to ensure persons with disabilities enjoy rights on an equal basis with others.

questions.question: What is the main human rights treaty in the Inter-American system?
options: American Convention on Human Rights (Pact of San José)
questions.explanation: The American Convention on Human Rights (1969), also known as the Pact of San José, is the main binding treaty. However, major states like the US and Canada have not ratified it.

questions.question: What was significant about Velásquez Rodríguez v. Honduras (1988)?
options: First case on freedom of expression
First contentious judgment of IACtHR, established state duty to investigate
First case against the United States
questions.explanation: Velásquez Rodríguez (1988) was the first contentious judgment of the Inter-American Court. It established that states have duties to prevent, investigate, punish, and provide reparation for human rights violations.

questions.question: What unique feature does the African Charter include that other regional systems don't?
options: Duties of individuals and peoples' rights
questions.explanation: The African Charter uniquely includes duties of individuals (Arts 27-29) and peoples' rights (Arts 19-24), such as the right to self-determination, development, peace, and a satisfactory environment.

questions.question: What is another name for the African Charter on Human and Peoples' Rights?
questions.explanation: The African Charter (1981) is also called the Banjul Charter after the city in The Gambia where it was adopted. It entered into force in 1986.

questions.question: Who is credited with proposing the 'three generations' of human rights?
questions.explanation: Czech jurist Karel Vasak proposed the three generations theory in 1977, linking them to the French Revolution motto: 1st gen (liberty) = civil/political; 2nd gen (equality) = economic/social/cultural; 3rd gen (fraternity) = solidarity rights.

questions.question: The 'three generations' theory is universally accepted in human rights scholarship.
questions.explanation: The theory is criticized for suggesting a hierarchy (1st gen more important), for being Western-centric, and for artificially separating interdependent rights. The Vienna Declaration (1993) affirmed all rights are 'indivisible and interdependent.'

questions.question: What is 'actio popularis' and is it allowed at the ECtHR?
options: A popular vote on cases; yes it's allowed
Bringing a case in the general public interest without being a victim; NOT allowed
A type of interim measure; yes it's allowed
Appeal to the Grand Chamber; yes it's allowed
questions.explanation: Actio popularis means bringing a case in the abstract or general public interest without claiming to be a victim. The ECtHR does NOT allow this - applicants must be 'victims' under Article 34.

questions.question: What is the 'fourth instance' doctrine at the ECtHR?
options: There are four levels of appeal
The ECtHR is not a fourth level of appeal to review domestic court decisions on facts/law
Cases must go through four domestic instances first
Four judges must agree for admissibility
questions.explanation: The 'fourth instance' doctrine means the ECtHR is not an appeal court to review domestic courts' assessment of facts or application of domestic law. It only examines whether Convention rights were violated.

questions.question: What did McCann v. UK establish about the right to life?
options: Use of lethal force must be 'absolutely necessary' and strictly proportionate
States have no positive obligations under Article 2
questions.explanation: McCann v. UK (1995) (Gibraltar shootings of IRA suspects) established that lethal force must be 'absolutely necessary' - a stricter test than the 'necessary in a democratic society' test for qualified rights.

questions.question: What did Gäfgen v. Germany concern?
options: Threat of torture during police interrogation and use of evidence
questions.explanation: Gäfgen v. Germany (2010) involved police threatening torture to find a kidnapped child. The Grand Chamber found Article 3 violation for the threat, but not Article 6 violation as the conviction wasn't based solely on the tainted evidence.

questions.question: What is the 'Selmouni threshold' regarding Article 3?
options: A minimum number of beatings to constitute torture
The Court may reclassify treatment as torture given evolving standards
questions.explanation: In Selmouni v. France (1999), the Court stated that acts previously classified as inhuman treatment might be classified as torture as the Convention is a 'living instrument' and standards evolve.

questions.question: What are the UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights (2011)?
options: A binding treaty on corporate liability
A framework based on Protect, Respect, Remedy pillars
questions.explanation: The UNGPs (Ruggie Principles) establish three pillars: State duty to Protect against business abuses, Corporate responsibility to Respect human rights, and Access to Remedy for victims.

questions.question: What are the SDGs?
questions.explanation: The 17 Sustainable Development Goals (2015-2030) are the UN's global development agenda. While not human rights instruments, many SDGs relate to human rights (poverty, health, education, equality, etc.).

questions.question: What is a 'special procedure' in the UN human rights system?
options: Emergency sessions of the Security Council
Independent experts or working groups with thematic or country mandates
questions.explanation: Special procedures are independent human rights experts (Special Rapporteurs, Working Groups) who report on thematic issues or country situations. They conduct country visits, receive communications, and report to the HRC.

questions.question: When was the Human Rights Council established?
questions.explanation: The Human Rights Council was established in 2006 by GA Resolution 60/251, replacing the Commission on Human Rights. It has 47 members elected by the GA for 3-year terms.

questions.question: How many members does the Human Rights Council have?
questions.explanation: The HRC has 47 members elected by the General Assembly. Seats are distributed regionally: Africa 13, Asia-Pacific 13, Latin America 8, Western Europe & Others 7, Eastern Europe 6.

questions.question: How many member states does the Council of Europe have (2024)?
questions.explanation: As of 2024, the Council of Europe has 46 member states. Russia was expelled in March 2022 following its invasion of Ukraine (previously 47 members).

questions.question: What is the CPT?
options: Court for the Protection of Treaties
Committee for the Prevention of Torture
questions.explanation: The CPT (European Committee for the Prevention of Torture) conducts visits to places of detention in CoE member states. It operates under the European Convention for the Prevention of Torture (1987).

questions.question: What is Article 15 ECHR about?
questions.explanation: Article 15 allows states to derogate from certain Convention rights 'in time of war or other public emergency threatening the life of the nation.' However, some rights are non-derogable (Art 2 except lawful war, Art 3, Art 4(1), Art 7).

questions.question: States can derogate from Article 3 ECHR (prohibition of torture) during a public emergency.
questions.explanation: Article 3 is one of the non-derogable rights under Article 15(2) ECHR. The prohibition of torture is absolute and applies even during war or emergency.

questions.question: When was the Universal Declaration of Human Rights adopted?
questions.explanation: The UDHR was adopted by the UN General Assembly on December 10, 1948 (now celebrated as Human Rights Day). It was drafted by a committee chaired by Eleanor Roosevelt.

questions.question: Who chaired the drafting committee of the UDHR?
questions.explanation: Eleanor Roosevelt chaired the UN Commission on Human Rights that drafted the UDHR. Key drafters included René Cassin (France), Charles Malik (Lebanon), Peng Chun Chang (China), and John Humphrey (Canada).

questions.question: How many articles does the UDHR have?
questions.explanation: The UDHR has 30 articles covering civil, political, economic, social, and cultural rights. It begins with recognition of 'inherent dignity' and 'equal and inalienable rights' of all people.

questions.question: The UDHR was originally legally binding on UN member states.
questions.explanation: The UDHR was adopted as a GA resolution, which is not legally binding. However, many provisions are now considered customary international law, and the rights were made binding through ICCPR and ICESCR.

questions.question: What is the 'International Bill of Rights'?
options: The US Bill of Rights applied internationally
The European Convention on Human Rights
All UN human rights treaties combined
questions.explanation: The International Bill of Rights refers to the UDHR, ICCPR, ICESCR, and their Optional Protocols. Together they form the foundation of the international human rights framework.

questions.question: When did Slovenia join the Council of Europe?
questions.explanation: Slovenia joined the Council of Europe on May 14, 1993, and ratified the ECHR on June 28, 1994. It was among the first ex-Yugoslav states to join.

questions.question: What was the 'Erased' (Izbrisani) case about in Slovenia?
options: People removed from permanent residence register after independence
questions.explanation: The 'Erased' refers to people (mostly from other ex-Yugoslav republics) who were illegally removed from Slovenia's permanent residence register in 1992. The issue was addressed by Constitutional Court decisions and ECtHR judgments.

questions.question: What is the 'López Ostra' case significant for?
questions.explanation: López Ostra v. Spain (1994) was groundbreaking for environmental protection. The Court found that severe environmental pollution can violate Article 8 (private and family life), even without serious health damage.

questions.question: What did Öneryıldız v. Turkey establish?
options: State's positive obligations under Article 2 regarding industrial/environmental dangers
questions.explanation: Öneryıldız v. Turkey (2004) concerned deaths from a methane explosion at a garbage dump near a slum. The Grand Chamber found Article 2 violations, establishing positive obligations to protect life from dangerous activities.

questions.question: What does 'exhaustion of domestic remedies' mean?
options: All money must be spent on lawyers
Applicants must use available national legal remedies before international complaints
Domestic courts are exhausted from cases
questions.explanation: Exhaustion of domestic remedies is an admissibility requirement. Applicants must give the state opportunity to remedy violations through its own legal system before bringing international complaints.

questions.question: When can the exhaustion requirement be waived?
options: When domestic remedies are ineffective, inadequate, or unavailable
questions.explanation: The exhaustion rule can be waived if domestic remedies are ineffective in practice, inadequate to address the violation, or unavailable (e.g., excessive cost, lack of legal aid, or demonstrated futility).

questions.question: What is the Handyside v. UK case famous for?
options: Freedom of expression includes information that 'offends, shocks or disturbs'
questions.explanation: Handyside v. UK (1976) established that Article 10 protects not only favorable information but also that which 'offends, shocks or disturbs the State or any sector of the population.' This is fundamental to free speech jurisprudence.

questions.question: What did Jersild v. Denmark concern?
options: Journalist convicted for broadcasting racist statements made by interviewees
questions.explanation: Jersild v. Denmark (1994) found a violation of Article 10 when a journalist was convicted for aiding dissemination of racist statements. The Court distinguished between reporting on racism and promoting it.

questions.question: What was S.A.S. v. France (2014) about?
options: Ban on wearing full-face veils in public
questions.explanation: S.A.S. v. France (Grand Chamber, 2014) upheld France's ban on full-face coverings in public, accepting 'living together' as a legitimate aim. The Court gave France a wide margin of appreciation.

questions.question: What is the principle of non-refoulement?
options: Right to return to one's country
Prohibition on returning someone to a place where they face persecution or serious harm
questions.explanation: Non-refoulement prohibits states from returning (refouler) individuals to countries where they face serious threats to life or freedom. It's a cornerstone of refugee law and Article 3 ECHR jurisprudence.

questions.question: What is the 1951 Refugee Convention's definition of a refugee?
options: Person with well-founded fear of persecution based on race, religion, nationality, political opinion, or membership in a particular social group
questions.explanation: Article 1A(2) defines a refugee as someone with 'well-founded fear of being persecuted for reasons of race, religion, nationality, membership of a particular social group or political opinion.'

questions.question: What is CAT?
options: Convention Against Torture and Other Cruel, Inhuman or Degrading Treatment
questions.explanation: CAT (1984) is the UN Convention against Torture and Other Cruel, Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment. It defines torture and establishes absolute prohibition.

questions.question: What is OPCAT?
options: Organization for Prevention of Child Abuse and Trafficking
Optional Protocol to CAT establishing preventive visiting mechanism
Office for Protection of Civilians in Armed Territories
Optional Protocol on Children and Armed Conflict
questions.explanation: OPCAT (2002) establishes the Subcommittee on Prevention of Torture and requires states to set up National Preventive Mechanisms to conduct visits to places of detention.

questions.question: What distinguishes torture from cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment under CAT?
options: Severity of pain/suffering, purposive element, and involvement of public official
questions.explanation: Under Article 1 CAT, torture requires: (1) severe pain or suffering, (2) inflicted for a purpose (information, punishment, intimidation, discrimination), (3) by or with consent of a public official.

questions.question: What rights does Article 8 ECHR protect?
options: Right to respect for private and family life, home and correspondence
questions.explanation: Article 8 protects four interests: private life, family life, home, and correspondence. It's a qualified right subject to limitations under Article 8(2).

questions.question: What is the three-part test for limitations on qualified ECHR rights?
options: Prescribed by law, legitimate aim, necessary in a democratic society
questions.explanation: Limitations on qualified rights (Articles 8-11) must be: (1) prescribed by law, (2) pursue a legitimate aim listed in the article, and (3) be necessary in a democratic society (proportionate).

questions.question: What is the 'proportionality' test in ECHR jurisprudence?
options: Rights must be proportional to duties
Balancing the interference against the aim pursued - means must be proportionate to the legitimate aim
questions.explanation: Proportionality requires that limitations on rights not exceed what is necessary to achieve the legitimate aim. The Court balances individual rights against public interests, considering less restrictive alternatives.

questions.question: What is 'legal positivism' in human rights theory?
options: Rights exist only when positive about them
Human rights exist only when enacted in positive law by states
questions.explanation: Legal positivism holds that rights exist only when recognized in positive law (treaties, constitutions, statutes). This contrasts with natural law theory, which holds rights exist independently of legal recognition.

questions.question: What does 'inalienable' mean regarding human rights?
options: Rights can be transferred to others
Rights cannot be given up, taken away, or transferred
questions.explanation: Inalienable means human rights cannot be sold, given away, or taken away (though they may be limited in certain circumstances). They are inherent to human dignity and cannot be forfeited.

questions.question: What does 'indivisibility' of human rights mean?
options: All rights are equally important and interdependent - cannot pick and choose
Rights only apply in undivided countries
questions.explanation: Indivisibility means all human rights (civil, political, economic, social, cultural) are equally important, interrelated, and interdependent. Violating one right affects others.

questions.question: What did the Vienna Declaration and Programme of Action (1993) affirm?
options: Human rights are only Western values
Human rights are universal, indivisible, interdependent and interrelated
questions.explanation: The Vienna Declaration (World Conference on Human Rights, 1993) affirmed that 'All human rights are universal, indivisible and interdependent and interrelated.' It rejected the hierarchy of rights.

questions.question: What is OHCHR?
options: Organization for Human and Civil Rights
Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights
questions.explanation: OHCHR is the UN Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights, established in 1993. It's the principal UN office for human rights, headed by the High Commissioner.

questions.question: What is a 'General Comment' or 'General Recommendation'?
options: Authoritative interpretation of treaty provisions by treaty bodies
questions.explanation: General Comments/Recommendations are authoritative interpretations of treaty provisions issued by treaty bodies. While not legally binding, they carry significant weight in interpreting state obligations.

questions.question: What are 'concluding observations' in the UN treaty body system?
options: Treaty body's assessment of a state's compliance after reviewing its periodic report
Observations at the end of treaty negotiations
questions.explanation: Concluding observations are issued by treaty bodies after examining a state party's periodic report. They identify concerns and make recommendations for improving implementation.

questions.question: What is an 'individual communication' to a UN treaty body?
options: Letter from one individual to another
Complaint mechanism allowing individuals to bring claims of treaty violations
questions.explanation: Individual communications are complaints brought by individuals claiming violation of treaty rights. Most UN treaties have Optional Protocols enabling this quasi-judicial procedure.

questions.question: What is 'R2P' or 'Responsibility to Protect'?
options: Framework for international response to genocide, war crimes, ethnic cleansing, crimes against humanity
questions.explanation: R2P (2005 World Summit) holds that states have primary responsibility to protect their populations from atrocity crimes. If they fail, the international community may intervene through the Security Council.

questions.question: What is 'intergenerational equity' in environmental rights?
options: Equal rights between generations of the same family
Responsibility to preserve the environment for future generations
questions.explanation: Intergenerational equity means present generations must preserve environmental resources and conditions for future generations. It's a key principle linking environmental protection to human rights.

questions.question: When did the UN recognize the right to a clean, healthy and sustainable environment?
questions.explanation: In July 2022, the UN General Assembly adopted a resolution declaring access to a clean, healthy and sustainable environment as a universal human right. This was a landmark decision after decades of advocacy.

questions.question: What is the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights?
options: EU's own bill of rights, legally binding since Lisbon Treaty (2009)
questions.explanation: The EU Charter of Fundamental Rights (2000) became legally binding with the Lisbon Treaty (2009). It applies to EU institutions and to member states when implementing EU law.

questions.question: What is FRA?
questions.explanation: FRA (EU Agency for Fundamental Rights, Vienna) provides evidence-based advice on fundamental rights issues in the EU. It assists EU institutions and member states with expertise and data.

questions.question: The EU has acceded to the European Convention on Human Rights.
questions.explanation: Despite Article 6(2) TEU requiring EU accession to the ECHR, the CJEU's Opinion 2/13 (2014) found the draft accession agreement incompatible with EU law. Negotiations continue but accession hasn't happened.

questions.question: What did Al-Skeini v. UK establish?
options: Extraterritorial application of ECHR when state exercises control
questions.explanation: Al-Skeini v. UK (2011) established that the ECHR applies extraterritorially when a state exercises control and authority over individuals, including in occupied territories like Iraq.

questions.question: What is the significance of M.S.S. v. Belgium and Greece?
options: Dublin Regulation transfers can violate Articles 3 and 13 if receiving state has inadequate asylum system
questions.explanation: M.S.S. v. Belgium and Greece (2011) found that Belgium violated Articles 3 and 13 by transferring an asylum seeker to Greece under Dublin, where detention and living conditions were inhuman.

questions.question: What does the ICJ's advisory opinion on the 'Wall' in Palestine (2004) address?
options: Legality of Israel's barrier in occupied Palestinian territory under international law
questions.explanation: The ICJ advisory opinion (2004) found the construction of the wall in occupied Palestinian territory violated international law, including humanitarian law and human rights obligations.

questions.question: What is 'backsliding' in human rights discourse?
options: Regression in human rights protection, often in established democracies
questions.explanation: Democratic or human rights backsliding refers to the erosion of democratic norms and human rights protections, often seen in attacks on judicial independence, media freedom, and civil society space.

questions.question: What does 'SOGI' stand for in human rights?
questions.explanation: SOGI refers to Sexual Orientation and Gender Identity rights. UN bodies have increasingly addressed discrimination based on SOGI, though this remains contested by some states.

questions.question: How often does the UPR review each UN member state?
questions.explanation: Each UN member state is reviewed approximately every 4.5 years through the UPR. The fourth cycle began in 2022. States submit reports and receive recommendations from other states.

questions.question: What are 'treaty bodies' in the UN system?
options: Committees of independent experts that monitor implementation of core human rights treaties
Political bodies of UN member states
questions.explanation: Treaty bodies are committees of independent experts (e.g., Human Rights Committee, CESCR) that monitor how states parties implement the core UN human rights treaties through reporting and complaints.

questions.question: What is a 'periodic report' under UN human rights treaties?
options: Report states must submit regularly describing measures taken to implement treaty rights
questions.explanation: States parties must submit periodic reports (usually every 4-5 years) to treaty bodies describing legislative, judicial, administrative and other measures they've taken to implement treaty obligations.

questions.question: What historical document from 1215 is considered an early precursor to human rights?
questions.explanation: Magna Carta (1215) limited the English king's power and established principles like due process. While not a human rights document per se, it's seen as an important historical precursor to modern rights.

questions.question: What was the French Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen?
options: 1789 declaration establishing fundamental rights during the French Revolution
questions.explanation: The French Declaration (1789) proclaimed individual rights and popular sovereignty during the Revolution. It influenced subsequent human rights documents and remains part of French constitutional law.
